description: In this inaugural episode of "Not Investment Advice," VCs Eric Bahn, Ian Park, and Kevin Jiang explore the rapid rise of prediction markets and their growing legitimacy. They analyze the trillion-dollar AI infrastructure bubble, the fierce competition for AI talent, and the emerging threat of Sora deepfakes to identity and public trust.
keyTakeaways: Prediction markets are transitioning from niche experiments to mainstream financial tools, with record trading volumes and increasing institutional interest.
The AI infrastructure sector faces bubble concerns due to massive investments and converging model architectures.
Competition for AI talent has intensified, marked by billion-dollar contracts and the growing importance of autonomous agents.
Sora deepfakes pose significant risks to intellectual property, identity security, and public trust, with implications for projects like Worldcoin and virtual actors.
Prediction markets offer real-time, crowd-sourced probabilities that outperform traditional polling and provide actionable data signals.
Regulatory clarity will be crucial for prediction markets' continued growth and institutional adoption.
